properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Substantial high-elevation snowfall expected. Snow will continue over western Newfoundland tonight and Wednesday, and will become heavy at times over elevated terrain. Accumulations are forecast to reach 20 to 30 cm along the highest parts of the Viking Trail between Wiltondale and Bonne Bay, while totals around 50 cm are likely across higher parts of the Long Range Mountains. The snow will begin to ease Wednesday night. Snowfall amounts in coastal communities will be much lower, with as little as 5 cm in some locations near sea level. Anyone considering using back-country trails or high-elevation roads should be aware of the large contrast in conditions. These routes may become difficult to navigate due to the accumulating snow. ### Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-05-01T10:16:45-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-30T18:17:45-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2305483736.2019
Area: Gros Morne, Parson's Pond - Hawke's Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Periods of snow or freezing precipitation Wednesday ... A low pressure system will cross the Great Lakes on Wednesday bringing a mixed bag of precipitation to the Outaouais region. Precipitation will begin mainly as rain midday Wednesday before changing over to snow over areas further north in the afternoon. The snow may change over to freezing rain Thursday evening or overnight. Rainfall amounts could approach 25 millimetres along the Ottawa River while areas further north see 5 centimetres of wet, heavy snow. Significant ice accretion is also possible before precipitation comes to an end Thursday morning. Possibly heavy rain could contribute to rising water levels. The wet, heavy snow and freezing precipitation could cause driving conditions to deteriorate and put significant weight on trees and power lines. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-05-01T01:42:13-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-30T17:43:13-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0332397243.2019
Area: Rapides-des-Joachims area, Fort William - Shawville area, Low - Wakefield area, Maniwaki - Gracefield area, Papineauville - Chénéville area, Papineau-Labelle Reserve area, Lièvre River area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory For La Plonge Ir #192
properties.Summary:
Description: A precautionary drinking water advisory has been issued for La Plonge IR #192. This advisory is for the residents of La Plonge Reserve and for any individuals who may access water from the La Plonge Reserve system. This advisory will be in effect until May 7, 2019.
Expires: 2019-05-07T16:00:00-06:00

Area: La Plonge IR #192
properties.Author: SK La Plonge FN

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rainfall amounts of 20 to 40 mm are expected. Rain is expected to return to the region beginning overnight Tuesday and ending early Thursday morning. Total rainfall amounts of 20 to 40 mm are forecast. The ground has limited ability to absorb further rainfall. Flood messaging is in effect for much of Central and Eastern Ontario. For information concerning flooding, please consult your local Conservation Authority or Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry District Office. This rainfall is associated with a Texas Low that will track across Southern Ontario Wednesday and Wednesday night. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-30T21:43:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-30T13:44:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3604897176.2019

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected Wednesday afternoon and evening. Precipitation will begin as snow and ice pellets Wednesday morning. Snow and ice pellet amounts of 2 to 5 cm are possible before the precipitation changes to freezing rain Wednesday afternoon. Freezing rain will last for several hours before changing to rain Wednesday night. This wintry precipitation is associated with a Texas Low that will track across Southern Ontario Wednesday and Wednesday night. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-05-01T04:07:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-30T19:08:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3463495420.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Northwesterly winds gusting to 90 kilometres per hour are expected today. ### Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

Area: Kangiqsujuaq - Raglan Lake

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A messy mix of snow and ice pellets beginning Wednesday morning changing to rain or freezing rain through the day. Snow and ice pellets amounts of 2 to 5 cm are possible before changing to rain or freezing rain Wednesday afternoon. However, with temperatures expected to remain near the zero degree mark there is uncertainty as to how much precipitation will fall as rain or freezing rain across the area. Areas of Eastern Ontario including Ottawa may receive some freezing rain Wednesday afternoon followed by rainfall amounts of 15 to 25 mm. The higher terrain areas near Algonquin Park are likely to receive significant freezing rain Wednesday afternoon and evening. Warnings may be issued as the event draws closer. For information concerning flooding, please consult your local Conservation Authority or Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry District Office. This precipitation is associated with a Texas Low that will track across Southern Ontario Wednesday and Wednesday night. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-30T21:40:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-30T13:41:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0975592398.2019
Area: Gatineau, South River - Burk's Falls, Deep River - Whitney - Eastern Algonquin Park, Western Algonquin Park - Lake of Two Rivers, Oxtongue Lake - Fort Irwin - Northern Haliburton County, Bancroft - Hastings Highlands - Denbigh, Prescott and Russell, Petawawa - Pembroke - Cobden, Barry's Bay - Killaloe, Renfrew - Arnprior - Calabogie, Smiths Falls - Perth - Eastern Lanark County, Ottawa North - Kanata - Orléans, Ottawa South - Richmond - Metcalfe
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Update: Flood Warning Continues For The Red River From Emerson To The Red River Floodway Channel Inlet
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure's Hydrologic Forecast Centre continues to issue a Flood Warning on the Red River from Emerson to the Red River Floodway channel inlet due to high water flows. If you are in the affected area, be watchful of local waterways as flooding is likely to occur. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters or waters of unknown depth. Avoid flooded areas. Follow all directions given by local authorities. Listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca or stay tuned to local media.
Expires: 2019-05-01T09:45:00-05:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2019-04-30T09:50:15-05:00, 0CA7A2F7-E0DE-CF4D-F859-0D2F718EC87F
Area: Red River from Emerson to the Red River Floodway channel inlet
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected. Flurries today, mixed with drizzle or freezing drizzle, are expected to give way to snow, at times heavy, by early tonight. Total accumulations are forecast to reach 15 to 20 cm along the coast, with substantially higher amounts inland and over higher terrain, before the snow tapers off early Wednesday. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Frost Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Frost may damage some crops in frost-prone areas. Overnight temperatures will drop to or slightly below the freezing mark. ### Frost advisories are issued when temperatures are expected to reach the freezing mark during the growing season, leading to potential damage and destruction to plants and crops. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-05-01T06:31:22-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-30T14:32:22-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3569570153.2019

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rainfall, combined with melting snow, is expected. The ground, already near saturation, has little ability to absorb further rainfall. Rainfall amounts of 20 to 35 mm are expected. Some areas will begin as snow or ice pellets before changing to rain in the morning. Local snow and ice pellet amounts of 2 cm are possible. Total rainfall amounts of 20 to 35 mm are possible by Thursday morning. Flood messaging is in effect for much of Central and Eastern Ontario. For information concerning flooding, please consult your local Conservation Authority or Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry District Office. This rainfall is associated with a Texas Low that will track across Southern Ontario Wednesday and Wednesday night. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-05-01T05:38:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-30T13:39:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0376155212.2019
Area: Huntsville - Baysville, Town of Parry Sound - Rosseau - Killbear Park, Port Carling - Port Severn, Bracebridge - Gravenhurst, Haliburton - Minden - Southern Haliburton County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Possible snow and freezing rain Wednesday evening... A low pressure system will track across the Great Lakes on Wednesday bringing a mixed bag of precipitation to the Laurentians. Precipitation will begin as snow on Wednesday in the late afternoon or early evening before changing over to freezing rain or rain toward midnight. Local accumulations of wet, heavy snow approaching 5 centimetres are expected Wednesday evening, especially over higher elevations. Significant ice accretion is also possible in some areas before precipitation comes to an end Thursday morning. Travel may be difficult due to snow and freezing precipitation. The weight of the snow and ice may impact trees and power lines. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-05-01T01:39:48-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-30T17:40:48-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2206829524.2019
Area: Mont-Tremblant - Sainte-Agathe area, Sainte-Adèle - Saint-Sauveur area
properties.Author: Environment Canada
